So there is definitely something wrong with the constant surface area for equal thickness slice claim. I am a physics student currently working on a computational research project which requires the division of a sphere into equal area slices and I know for a fact that slice thickness has to change in order to keep area constant.

The proof that the video's claim is not true is fairly simple, requiring only single variable calculus to show. The claim is that the area of a slice (dA) is proportional to the thickness of a slice (dh) and independent of the height where the slice is taken (h).

Using Riemann sums, we can imagine slicing out a horizontal sliver from a sphere of differential thickness dh. Allowing dh to be appropriately small, this sliver would be cylindrical (in the limit) allowing us to write the surface area as dA = 2*Pi*r*dh.

At this point it is very easy to say "aha, there is no dependence on h, so equal thickness slices will have equal area". But this logic has a slight flaw, it assumes that r (the area of our differential cylinder) is R (the area of our sphere).

It turns out, using right triangles and the Pythagorean theorem that r^2 = R^2 - h^2.

So really dA = 2*Pi*sqrt(R^2 - h^2)*dh

If we were to integrate from some arbitrary height H to H+t, where t represents thickness, the H terms would not cancel, and we would find height dependence.

So equal slices do not have equal area!

The area depends on where the slice is taken from in the sphere.

Question though. wouldn't the important thing for land dwelling creatures (LDC's) be the horizontal projected area?  sort of the amount of area that would exist if you built a level platform of size X at the highest point in the area covered by your platform?

LDC's don't live perpendicular to the ground, they live perpendicular to the force of gravity, to avoid falling over.  So more surface area (say, on the vertical side of a cliff) wouldn't do a LDC any good, because they can't use it.

However, is it not so that if we wanted to build something on a mountain, we would (for relatively normal structures) need horizontal surface area? In that case mountains would still be smaller the further up you go.

But this is still pretty neat for other applications :)

Hello.
I actually love the content you produce in your videos, and my comment is absolutely not meant to be critical. keep on the work !
In this video ( the one about the mountains ), you pretend that if you have a sphere, that you cut it in X parts of even heights, those X parts will have the exact same surface. It can be explained by the fact that as the sphere grow thinier at the bottom, it aslo get wider (from a diving point of view ). That seems logical.
But we can see a sphere as the gathering of an infinite number of co-centred circles, each one between two other, forming a pile. Since each of our X parts has the same height, it is composed of the same number of circles ( a infinity ). We aslo notice that the radius of the co-centred circles is growing smaller as we reach the poles. The surface being the addition of the perimeters ( I guess the math must be an "integral" ) of every circles of  the part, it should decrease as it get closer to the poles ?
Could you please explain me/us how it works, this part trully puzzles me.

I just realized that you can very easily derive the formula for surface area of a sphere from the fact that every slice of an evenly sliced orange will have the same amount of skin. Just use an infinitesimally small thickness r/n (n -> infinity). A = 2r*n (number of slices) * 2pi*r/n (surface area of the slice in the middle) = 4pi*r².
